title: Reduce onboarding steps to increase activation rate
business_context: New users drop off heavily during the onboarding funnel, leading to lower activation rates and fewer users reaching meaningful first actions.
problem_statement: Current onboarding flow has 6 steps and a 40% drop-off at step 3. Activation (users completing first meaningful action) is only 22%. We believe complexity is the primary barrier.
hypothesis: If we reduce onboarding steps from 6 to 3 and auto-fill known information, activation rate will increase by 25% because users face less friction.
success_metrics: North Star: Activation rate (users completing key first action)
experiment_design: Run a 50/50 A/B test comparing the 6-step (control) vs 3-step (variant) onboarding flow. Measure activation over 14 days post-signup, with statistical significance at 95% confidence.
implementation_plan: Audit current onboarding flow and identify redundant fields.
Introduce progressive disclosure and auto-fill known details.
Deploy experiment via feature flag and monitor via analytics dashboard.

risks_and_mitigations.risk: Reduced onboarding detail may lead to incomplete profiles.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Collect missing info gradually post-onboarding (soft gates).
Monitor engagement metrics of new users separately.

decision_framework: If activation rate improves by ≥20% with no significant drop in retention or engagement, roll out to 100% of new users.

title: Optimize landing page CTAs to increase signup conversion
business_context: Our main acquisition channel drives 150K visits/month but conversion to sign-up is low (~2.8%). Users bounce early due to weak messaging hierarchy and CTA placement.
problem_statement: Conversion rate from homepage to signup is below industry benchmarks (2.8% vs 4-6%). Heatmap analysis shows CTA below the fold, low engagement.
hypothesis: If we move CTAs above the fold and personalize messaging by referral source, homepage-to-signup conversion will increase by 30%.
success_metrics: North Star: Homepage to signup conversion rate
experiment_design: Run multi-variant A/B test with 3 CTA placements and messaging variants. Segment by acquisition source (ads, organic, social). Duration: 3 weeks.
implementation_plan: Redesign hero section with multiple CTA placements.
Add dynamic text personalization via UTM parameters.
Run experiment using growth experimentation platform.

risks_and_mitigations.risk: Aggressive CTAs may reduce brand trust.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Use subtle design cues; test visual tone through surveys.
Default to generic but tested copy.

decision_framework: If variant increases conversion by ≥20% without significant rise in bounce rate, roll out globally.

title: Introduce referral program to drive organic acquisition
business_context: Paid acquisition costs are rising 15% MoM. Organic growth has plateaued. A structured referral program can convert existing satisfied users into acquisition channels.
problem_statement: CAC from paid channels has crossed $18, while referral-driven users (in ad-hoc tests) show higher retention and LTV. Currently, there’s no incentivized referral path.
hypothesis: If we introduce a structured referral system (referrer gets $5 credit, referee gets 7-day premium trial), organic new users will increase by 20% MoM and LTV will improve by 10%.
success_metrics: North Star: Referral-driven new user growth
experiment_design: Launch a referral program to 20% of existing user base. Measure referral invites, conversion rate, and quality (D30 retention).
implementation_plan: Build referral link generator and tracking dashboard.
Automate incentive distribution.
Promote feature via in-app banners and email.

risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Limit rewards per user and flag suspicious patterns.
Integrate QA testing for incentive distribution.

decision_framework: Scale program if net-new users via referral ≥10% of total acquisition and cost/user < CAC_baseline.

title: Add progress indicators to boost onboarding completion
business_context: Behavioral research shows users complete processes more often when progress is visualized. Onboarding completion has stagnated at 62%.
problem_statement: No progress visualization in current onboarding flow. Users lack feedback on completion, leading to frustration and abandonment.
hypothesis: If we introduce a progress bar and milestone feedback, onboarding completion will increase by 15% because users gain visibility and motivation.
experiment_design: A/B test progress indicator (visual bar) vs. no indicator. Duration: 14 days, targeting new signups.
implementation_plan: Add progress bar UI at top of onboarding screens.
Show celebratory message at completion.
Monitor funnel metrics and user sentiment.

risks_and_mitigations.risk: Incorrect progress calculation could confuse users.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Double-check event triggers and progress logic.

decision_framework: Roll out if completion improves ≥10% with no negative effect on activation or D7 retention.

title: Introduce exit-intent modals to recover drop-offs
business_context: 40% of users drop from pricing or checkout pages without converting. Exit-intent offers can reduce abandonment and boost paid conversions.
problem_statement: High cart abandonment rate (68%) compared to benchmark (55%). No intervention exists before users exit the page.
hypothesis: If we show an exit-intent modal offering 10% discount or reminder email capture, abandonment will reduce by 20% and conversions increase by 10%.
experiment_design: A/B test: Control (no modal) vs Variant (exit modal). Target high-intent users on pricing and checkout pages. Measure conversions over 2 weeks.
implementation_plan: Implement exit-intent detection (mouse leave + idle timeout).
Design modal offering limited-time discount or email capture.
Measure conversions, track re-engagement via email.

risks_and_mitigations.risk: Overuse of modals could annoy users.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Cap display frequency to once per user/session.

decision_framework: Deploy globally if conversion lift ≥8% and churn of discounted users ≤ control group.

title: Add social proof widgets to boost signup trust
business_context: New users show hesitation on signup page; heatmaps reveal idle time near form fields. Lack of trust signals may be causing friction.
problem_statement: Only 2.9% of visitors complete signup. Qualitative feedback indicates users doubt platform credibility.
hypothesis: If we display dynamic social proof (e.g., ‘2,000 users signed up this week’) and trust badges, signup rate will increase by 12%.
experiment_design: 50/50 A/B test on signup page with vs without social proof widgets. Track conversion uplift and confidence intervals.
implementation_plan: Integrate live user counter and testimonial carousel.
Add security and payment trust badges.
Validate copy through micro-surveys pre-launch.

risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Use accurate, real-time numbers with proof source.

decision_framework: Roll out if uplift ≥10% and post-signup churn unaffected.

title: Launch in-app checklist to improve first-week engagement
business_context: New users often miss key setup actions (profile completion, first project creation). Engagement drops after day 3, hurting retention and monetization potential.
problem_statement: Only 38% of new users complete core setup tasks within first 3 days. No guidance or nudges exist to encourage progress.
hypothesis: If we introduce a gamified checklist guiding first 5 actions, day-7 retention and activation will increase by 15%.
experiment_design: Roll out checklist feature to 30% of new users. Monitor engagement, retention, and activation over 2 weeks.
implementation_plan: Design in-app checklist with progress bar and badges.
Track completion and time-to-completion metrics.
Add optional reminder notifications for incomplete tasks.

risks_and_mitigations.risk: Users may perceive checklist as spammy or intrusive.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Allow dismissal and customize frequency of reminders.

decision_framework: Full rollout if checklist users show ≥12% higher D7 retention and ≥10% higher activation.
